translation_text.dn16:1.31.14: When the Buddha had expressed his appreciation to Sunidha and Vassakāra with these verses, he got up from his seat and left.
translation_text.dn16:1.32.1: Sunidha and Vassakāra followed behind the Buddha, thinking,
translation_text.dn16:1.32.2: “The gate through which the ascetic Gotama exits today shall be named the Gotama Gate.
translation_text.dn16:1.32.3: The ford at which he crosses the Ganges River shall be named the Gotama Ford.”
translation_text.dn16:1.32.4: Then the gate through which the Buddha exited was named the Gotama Gate.
translation_text.dn16:1.32.5: Then the Buddha came to the Ganges River.
translation_text.dn16:1.33.1: Now at that time the Ganges was full to the brim so a crow could drink from it.
translation_text.dn16:1.33.2: Wanting to cross from the near to the far shore, some people were seeking a boat, some a dinghy, while some were tying up a raft.
translation_text.dn16:1.33.3: But, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, the Buddha, together with the mendicant Saṅgha, vanished from the near shore and landed on the far shore.
translation_text.dn16:1.34.1: He saw all those humans wanting to cross over.
translation_text.dn16:1.34.2: Knowing the meaning of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
translation_text.dn16:1.34.3: “Those who cross a deluge or stream
translation_text.dn16:1.34.4: have built a bridge and left the marshes behind.
translation_text.dn16:1.34.5: While some people are still tying a raft,
translation_text.dn16:2.1.1: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Ānanda,
translation_text.dn16:2.1.2: “Come, Ānanda, let’s go to the village of Koṭi.”
translation_text.dn16:2.1.4: Then the Buddha together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants arrived at the village of Koṭi,
translation_text.dn16:2.2.2: “Mendicants, due to not understanding and not penetrating four noble truths, both you and I have wandered and transmigrated for such a very long time.
translation_text.dn16:2.2.7: and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
translation_text.dn16:2.2.8: These noble truths of suffering, origin, cessation, and the path have been understood and comprehended. Craving for continued existence has been cut off; the leash to existence is ended; now there’ll be no more future lives.”
translation_text.dn16:2.3.1: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.dn16:2.3.2: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
translation_text.dn16:2.3.5: we have transmigrated for a long time
translation_text.dn16:2.3.6: from one rebirth to the next.
translation_text.dn16:2.3.7: But now that these truths have been seen,
translation_text.dn16:2.3.8: the leash to existence is eradicated.
translation_text.dn16:2.3.9: The root of suffering is cut off,
translation_text.dn16:2.3.10: now there’ll be no more future lives.”
translation_text.dn16:2.4.1: And while staying at the village of Koṭi, too, the Buddha often gave this Dhamma talk to the mendicants:
translation_text.dn16:2.4.2: “Such is ethics, such is immersion, such is wisdom.
translation_text.dn16:2.4.3: When immersion is imbued with ethics it’s very fruitful and beneficial.
translation_text.dn16:2.4.4: When wisdom is imbued with immersion it’s very fruitful and beneficial.
translation_text.dn16:2.4.5: When the mind is imbued with wisdom it is rightly freed from the defilements, namely,
translation_text.dn16:2.4.6: the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.”
translation_text.dn16:2.5.1: When the Buddha had stayed in the village of Koṭi as long as he pleased, he said to Ānanda,
translation_text.dn16:2.5.2: “Come, Ānanda, let’s go to the land of the Ñātikas.”
translation_text.dn16:2.5.4: Then the Buddha together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants arrived in the land of the Ñātikas,
translation_text.dn16:2.5.5: where he stayed in the brick house at Ñātika.
translation_text.dn16:2.6.1: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
translation_text.dn16:2.6.2: “Sir, the monk named Sāḷha has passed away in Ñātika. Where has he been reborn in his next life?
translation_text.dn16:2.6.5: and the laywoman named Sujātā have passed away in Ñātika. Where have they been reborn in the next life?
translation_text.dn16:2.6.13: Subhadda have passed away in Ñātika. Where have they been reborn in the next life?”
translation_text.dn16:2.7.1: “Ānanda, the monk Sāḷha had realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, having realized it with his own insight due to the ending of defilements.
translation_text.dn16:2.7.2: The nun Nandā had ended the five lower fetters. She’s been reborn spontaneously, and will be extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.
translation_text.dn16:2.7.3: The layman Sudatta had ended three fetters, and weakened greed, hate, and delusion. He’s a once-returner; he will come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering.
translation_text.dn16:2.7.4: The laywoman Sujātā had ended three fetters. She’s a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.
translation_text.dn16:2.7.12: and Subhadda had ended the five lower fetters. They’ve been reborn spontaneously, and will be extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.
translation_text.dn16:2.7.13: Over fifty laymen in Ñātika have passed away having ended the five lower fetters. They’ve been reborn spontaneously, and will be extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.
translation_text.dn16:2.7.14: More than ninety laymen in Ñātika have passed away having ended three fetters, and weakened greed, hate, and delusion. They’re once-returners, who will come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering.
translation_text.dn16:2.7.15: More than five hundred laymen in Ñātika have passed away having ended three fetters. They’re stream-enterers, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.
translation_text.dn16:2.8.1: It’s no wonder that a human being should pass away.
translation_text.dn16:2.8.2: But if you should come and ask me about it each and every time someone passes away, that would be a bother for me.
translation_text.dn16:2.8.3: So Ānanda, I will teach you the explanation of the Dhamma named ‘the mirror of the teaching’. A noble disciple who has this may declare of themselves:
translation_text.dn16:2.8.4: ‘I’ve finished with rebirth in hell, the animal realm, and the ghost realm. I’ve finished with all places of loss, bad places, the underworld. I am a stream-enterer! I’m not liable to be reborn in the underworld, and am destined for awakening.’
translation_text.dn16:2.9.1: And what is that mirror of the teaching?
translation_text.dn16:2.9.3: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha:
translation_text.dn16:2.9.4: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
translation_text.dn16:2.9.5: They have experiential confidence in the teaching:
translation_text.dn16:2.9.6: ‘The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.’
translation_text.dn16:2.9.7: They have experiential confidence in the Saṅgha:
translation_text.dn16:2.9.8: ‘The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is practicing the way that’s good, direct, systematic, and proper. It consists of the four pairs, the eight individual persons. This is the Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples that is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.’
translation_text.dn16:2.9.9: And a noble disciple’s ethical conduct is loved by the noble ones, unbroken, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion.
translation_text.dn16:2.9.10: This is that mirror of the teaching.”
translation_text.dn16:2.10.1: And while staying there in Ñātika the Buddha often gave this Dhamma talk to the mendicants:
translation_text.dn16:2.10.2: “Such is ethics, such is immersion, such is wisdom.
translation_text.dn16:2.10.3: When immersion is imbued with ethics it’s very fruitful and beneficial.
translation_text.dn16:2.10.4: When wisdom is imbued with immersion it’s very fruitful and beneficial.
translation_text.dn16:2.10.5: When the mind is imbued with wisdom it is rightly freed from the defilements, namely,
translation_text.dn16:2.10.6: the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.”
translation_text.dn16:2.11.1: When the Buddha had stayed in Ñātika as long as he pleased, he addressed Venerable Ānanda,
translation_text.dn16:2.11.4: Then the Buddha together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants arrived at Vesālī,
translation_text.dn16:2.11.5: where he stayed in Ambapālī’s mango grove.
translation_text.dn16:2.12.1: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
translation_text.dn16:2.12.2: “Mendicants, a mendicant should live mindful and aware.
translation_text.dn16:2.12.3: This is my instruction to you.
translation_text.dn16:2.12.4: And how is a mendicant mindful?
translation_text.dn16:2.12.5: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
translation_text.dn16:2.12.6: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …
translation_text.dn16:2.12.8: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
translation_text.dn16:2.12.9: That’s how a mendicant is mindful.
translation_text.dn16:2.13.1: And how is a mendicant aware?
translation_text.dn16:2.13.2: It’s when a mendicant acts with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
translation_text.dn16:2.13.3: That’s how a mendicant is aware.
translation_text.dn16:2.13.4: A mendicant should live mindful and aware.
translation_text.dn16:2.13.5: This is my instruction to you.”
translation_text.dn16:2.14.1: Ambapālī the courtesan heard that the Buddha had arrived and was staying in her mango grove.
translation_text.dn16:2.14.2: She had the finest carriages harnessed. Then she mounted a fine carriage and, along with other fine carriages, set out from Vesālī for her own park.
translation_text.dn16:2.14.3: She went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached the Buddha on foot. She bowed and sat down to one side.
translation_text.dn16:2.14.4: The Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired her with a Dhamma talk.
translation_text.dn16:2.14.5: Then she said to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn16:2.14.6: “Sir, may the Buddha together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me.”
translation_text.dn16:2.14.8: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, Ambapālī got up from her seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on her right, before leaving.
translation_text.dn16:2.15.1: The Licchavis of Vesālī also heard that the Buddha had arrived and was staying in Ambapālī’s mango grove.
translation_text.dn16:2.15.2: They had the finest carriages harnessed. Then they mounted a fine carriage and, along with other fine carriages, set out from Vesālī.
translation_text.dn16:2.15.3: Some of the Licchavis were in blue, of blue color, clad in blue, adorned with blue. And some were similarly colored in yellow, red, or white.
translation_text.dn16:2.16.1: Then Ambapālī the courtesan collided with those Licchavi youths, axle to axle, wheel to wheel, yoke to yoke.
translation_text.dn16:2.16.3: “What, you wench Ambapālī, are you doing colliding with us axle to axle, wheel to wheel, yoke to yoke?”
translation_text.dn16:2.16.4: “Well, masters, it’s because I’ve invited the Buddha for tomorrow’s meal together with the mendicant Saṅgha.”
translation_text.dn16:2.16.5: “Wench, give us that meal for a hundred thousand!”
translation_text.dn16:2.16.6: “Masters, even if you were to give me Vesālī with her provinces, I still wouldn’t give that meal to you.”
translation_text.dn16:2.16.7: Then the Licchavis snapped their fingers, saying,
translation_text.dn16:2.16.8: “We’ve been beaten by the aunty! We’ve been beaten by the aunty!”
translation_text.dn16:2.16.9: Then they continued on to Ambapālī’s mango grove.
translation_text.dn16:2.17.1: The Buddha saw them coming off in the distance,
translation_text.dn16:2.17.3: “Any of the mendicants who’ve never seen the gods of the thirty-three before, just have a look at the assembly of Licchavis.
translation_text.dn16:2.18.1: The Licchavis went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached the Buddha on foot. They bowed to the Buddha, sat down to one side,
translation_text.dn16:2.18.2: and the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired them with a Dhamma talk.
translation_text.dn16:2.18.3: Then they said to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn16:2.18.4: “Sir, may the Buddha together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from us.”
translation_text.dn16:2.18.5: Then the Buddha said to the Licchavis,
translation_text.dn16:2.18.6: “I have already accepted tomorrow’s meal from Ambapālī the courtesan.”
translation_text.dn16:2.18.7: Then the Licchavis snapped their fingers, saying,
translation_text.dn16:2.18.8: “We’ve been beaten by the aunty! We’ve been beaten by the aunty!”
translation_text.dn16:2.18.9: And then those Licchavis approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. They got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right, before leaving.
translation_text.dn16:2.19.1: And when the night had passed Ambapālī had delicious fresh and cooked foods prepared in her own park. Then she had the Buddha informed of the time, saying,
translation_text.dn16:2.19.2: “Sir, it’s time. The meal is ready.”
translation_text.dn16:2.19.3: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the home of Ambapālī together with the mendicant Saṅgha, where he sat on the seat spread out.
translation_text.dn16:2.19.4: Then Ambapālī served and satisfied the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha with her own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.
translation_text.dn16:2.19.5: When the Buddha had eaten and washed his hands and bowl, Ambapālī took a low seat, sat to one side,
translation_text.dn16:2.19.7: “Sir, I present this park to the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha.”
translation_text.dn16:2.19.9: Then the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired her with a Dhamma talk, after which he got up from his seat and left.
translation_text.dn16:2.20.1: And while staying at Vesālī, too, the Buddha often gave this Dhamma talk to the mendicants:
translation_text.dn16:2.20.2: “Such is ethics, such is immersion, such is wisdom.
translation_text.dn16:2.20.3: When immersion is imbued with ethics it’s very fruitful and beneficial.
translation_text.dn16:2.20.4: When wisdom is imbued with immersion it’s very fruitful and beneficial.
translation_text.dn16:2.20.5: When the mind is imbued with wisdom it is rightly freed from the defilements, namely,
translation_text.dn16:2.20.6: the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.”
translation_text.dn16:2.21.1: When the Buddha had stayed in Ambapālī’s mango grove as long as he pleased, he addressed Venerable Ānanda,
translation_text.dn16:2.21.2: “Come, Ānanda, let’s go to the little village of Beluva.”
translation_text.dn16:2.21.4: Then the Buddha together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants arrived at the little village of Beluva,
translation_text.dn16:2.22.1: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
translation_text.dn16:2.22.2: “Mendicants, please enter the rainy season residence with whatever friends or acquaintances you have around Vesālī.
translation_text.dn16:2.22.3: I’ll commence the rainy season residence right here in the little village of Beluva.”
translation_text.dn16:2.22.4: “Yes, sir,” those mendicants replied. They did as the Buddha said,
translation_text.dn16:2.22.5: while the Buddha commenced the rainy season residence right there in the little village of Beluva.
translation_text.dn16:2.23.1: After the Buddha had commenced the rainy season residence, he fell severely ill, struck by dreadful pains, close to death.
translation_text.dn16:2.23.2: But he endured unbothered, with mindfulness and situational awareness.
translation_text.dn16:2.23.3: Then it occurred to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn16:2.23.4: “It would not be appropriate for me to be fully extinguished before informing my supporters and taking leave of the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.dn16:2.23.5: Why don’t I forcefully suppress this illness, stabilize the life force, and live on?”
translation_text.dn16:2.24.1: So that is what he did.
translation_text.dn16:2.24.2: Then the Buddha’s illness died down.
translation_text.dn16:2.24.3: Soon after the Buddha had recovered from that sickness, he came out from his dwelling and sat in the shade of the porch on the seat spread out.
translation_text.dn16:2.24.4: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
translation_text.dn16:2.24.5: “Sir, it’s fantastic that the Buddha is comfortable and well. Because when the Buddha was sick, my body felt like it was drugged. I was disorientated, and the teachings weren’t clear to me.
translation_text.dn16:2.24.6: Still, at least I was consoled by the thought that
translation_text.dn16:2.24.7: the Buddha won’t be fully extinguished without bringing something up regarding the Saṅgha of mendicants.”
translation_text.dn16:2.25.1: “But what could the mendicant Saṅgha expect from me, Ānanda?
translation_text.dn16:2.25.2: I’ve taught the Dhamma without making any distinction between secret and public teachings.
translation_text.dn16:2.25.3: The Realized One doesn’t have the closed fist of a tutor when it comes to the teachings.
translation_text.dn16:2.25.5: ‘I shall lead the mendicant Saṅgha,’ or ‘the Saṅgha of mendicants is meant for me,’ let them bring something up regarding the Saṅgha.
translation_text.dn16:2.25.6: But the Realized One doesn’t think like this,
translation_text.dn16:2.25.8: so why should he bring something up regarding the Saṅgha?
translation_text.dn16:2.25.9: I’m now old, elderly and senior. I’m advanced in years and have reached the final stage of life.
translation_text.dn16:2.25.11: Just as a decrepit old cart is kept going by a rope,
translation_text.dn16:2.25.12: in the same way, the Realized One’s body is kept going as if by a rope.
translation_text.dn16:2.25.13: Sometimes the Realized One, not focusing on any signs, and with the cessation of certain feelings, enters and remains in the signless immersion of the heart. Only then does the Realized One’s body become more comfortable.
translation_text.dn16:2.26.1: So Ānanda, live as your own island, your own refuge, with no other refuge. Let the teaching be your island and your refuge, with no other refuge.
translation_text.dn16:2.26.2: And how does a mendicant do this?
translation_text.dn16:2.26.3: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
translation_text.dn16:2.26.4: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …
translation_text.dn16:2.26.6: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
translation_text.dn16:2.26.7: That’s how a mendicant is their own island, their own refuge, with no other refuge. That’s how the teaching is their island and their refuge, with no other refuge.
translation_text.dn16:2.26.8: Whether now or after I have passed, any who shall live as their own island, their own refuge, with no other refuge; with the teaching as their island and their refuge, with no other refuge—those mendicants of mine who want to train shall be among the best of the best.”
translation_text.dn16:3.1.1: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Vesālī for alms.
translation_text.dn16:3.1.2: Then, after the meal, on his return from almsround, he addressed Venerable Ānanda:
translation_text.dn16:3.1.4: Let’s go to the Cāpāla Shrine for the day’s meditation.”
translation_text.dn16:3.1.5: “Yes, sir,” replied Ānanda. Taking his sitting cloth he followed behind the Buddha.
translation_text.dn16:3.2.1: Then the Buddha went up to the Cāpāla Shrine, where he sat on the seat spread out.
translation_text.dn16:3.2.2: Ānanda bowed to the Buddha and sat down to one side.
translation_text.dn16:3.2.4: “Ānanda, Vesālī is lovely. And the Udena, Gotamaka, Seven Maidens, Many Sons, Sārandada, and Cāpāla Shrines are all lovely.
translation_text.dn16:3.3.1: Whoever has developed and cultivated the four bases of psychic power—made them a vehicle and a basis, kept them up, consolidated them, and properly implemented them—may, if they wish, live for the proper lifespan or what’s left of it.
translation_text.dn16:3.3.2: The Realized One has developed and cultivated the four bases of psychic power, made them a vehicle and a basis, kept them up, consolidated them, and properly implemented them. If he wished, the Realized One could live for the proper lifespan or what’s left of it.”
translation_text.dn16:3.4.1: But Ānanda didn’t get it, even though the Buddha dropped such an obvious hint, such a clear sign.
translation_text.dn16:3.4.3: “Sir, may the Blessed One please remain for the proper lifespan! May the Holy One please remain for the proper lifespan! That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.” For his mind was as if possessed by Māra.
translation_text.dn16:3.5.2: And for a third time, the Buddha said to Ānanda:
translation_text.dn16:3.5.3: “Ānanda, Vesālī is lovely. And the Udena, Gotamaka, Seven Maidens, Many Sons, Sārandada, and Cāpāla Shrines are all lovely.
translation_text.dn16:3.5.4: Whoever has developed and cultivated the four bases of psychic power—made them a vehicle and a basis, kept them up, consolidated them, and properly implemented them—may, if they wish, live for the proper lifespan or what’s left of it.
translation_text.dn16:3.5.5: The Realized One has developed and cultivated the four bases of psychic power, made them a vehicle and a basis, kept them up, consolidated them, and properly implemented them. If he wished, the Realized One could live for the proper lifespan or what’s left of it.”
translation_text.dn16:3.5.6: But Ānanda didn’t get it, even though the Buddha dropped such an obvious hint, such a clear sign.
translation_text.dn16:3.5.8: “Sir, may the Blessed One please remain for the proper lifespan! May the Holy One please remain for the proper lifespan! That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.” For his mind was as if possessed by Māra.
translation_text.dn16:3.6.1: Then the Buddha got up and said to Venerable Ānanda,
translation_text.dn16:3.6.4: “Yes, sir,” replied Ānanda. He rose from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before sitting at the root of a tree close by.
translation_text.dn16:3.7.1: And then, not long after Ānanda had left, Māra the Wicked went up to the Buddha, stood to one side, and said to him:
translation_text.dn16:3.7.2: “Sir, may the Blessed One now be fully extinguished! May the Holy One now be fully extinguished! Now is the time for the full extinguishment of the Buddha.
translation_text.dn16:3.7.3: Sir, you once made this statement:
translation_text.dn16:3.7.4: ‘Wicked One, I shall not be fully extinguished until I have monk disciples who are competent, educated, assured, learned, have memorized the teachings, and practice in line with the teaching. Not until they practice properly, living in line with the teaching. Not until they’ve learned their tradition, and explain, teach, assert, establish, disclose, analyze, and make it clear. Not until they can legitimately and completely refute the doctrines of others that come up, and teach with a demonstrable basis.’
translation_text.dn16:3.8.1: Today you do have such monk disciples.
translation_text.dn16:3.8.2: May the Blessed One now be fully extinguished! May the Holy One now be fully extinguished! Now is the time for the full extinguishment of the Buddha.
translation_text.dn16:3.8.3: Sir, you once made this statement:
translation_text.dn16:3.8.4: ‘Wicked One, I shall not be fully extinguished until I have nun disciples who are competent, educated, assured, learned …’
translation_text.dn16:3.8.5: Today you do have such nun disciples.
translation_text.dn16:3.8.6: May the Blessed One now be fully extinguished! May the Holy One now be fully extinguished! Now is the time for the full extinguishment of the Buddha.
translation_text.dn16:3.8.7: Sir, you once made this statement:
translation_text.dn16:3.8.8: ‘Wicked One, I shall not be fully extinguished until I have layman disciples who are competent, educated, assured, learned …’
translation_text.dn16:3.8.9: Today you do have such layman disciples.
translation_text.dn16:3.8.10: May the Blessed One now be fully extinguished! May the Holy One now be fully extinguished! Now is the time for the full extinguishment of the Buddha.
translation_text.dn16:3.8.11: Sir, you once made this statement:
translation_text.dn16:3.8.12: ‘Wicked One, I shall not be fully extinguished until I have laywoman disciples who are competent, educated, assured, learned …’
translation_text.dn16:3.8.13: Today you do have such laywoman disciples.
translation_text.dn16:3.8.14: May the Blessed One now be fully extinguished! May the Holy One now be fully extinguished! Now is the time for the full extinguishment of the Buddha.
translation_text.dn16:3.8.15: Sir, you once made this statement:
translation_text.dn16:3.8.16: ‘Wicked One, I will not be fully extinguished until my spiritual path is successful and prosperous, extensive, popular, widespread, and well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans.’
translation_text.dn16:3.8.17: Today your spiritual path is successful and prosperous, extensive, popular, widespread, and well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans.
translation_text.dn16:3.8.18: May the Blessed One now be fully extinguished! May the Holy One now be fully extinguished! Now is the time for the full extinguishment of the Buddha.”
translation_text.dn16:3.9.1: When this was said, the Buddha said to Māra,
translation_text.dn16:3.9.2: “Relax, Wicked One. The full extinguishment of the Realized One will be soon.
translation_text.dn16:3.9.3: Three months from now the Realized One will be fully extinguished.”
translation_text.dn16:3.10.1: So at the Cāpāla Shrine the Buddha, mindful and aware, surrendered the life force.
translation_text.dn16:3.10.2: When he did so there was a great earthquake, awe-inspiring and hair-raising, and thunder cracked the sky.
translation_text.dn16:3.10.3: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
translation_text.dn16:3.10.4: “Comparing the incomparable <j>with the creation of prolonged life,
translation_text.dn16:3.10.5: the sage surrendered the life force.
translation_text.dn16:3.10.7: he shattered self-creation like a suit of armor.”
translation_text.dn16:3.11.2: “How incredible, how amazing! That was a really big earthquake!
translation_text.dn16:3.11.3: That was really a very big earthquake; awe-inspiring and hair-raising, and thunder cracked the sky!
translation_text.dn16:3.11.4: What’s the cause, what’s the reason for a great earthquake?”
translation_text.dn16:3.12.1: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn16:3.12.2: bowed, sat down to one side,
translation_text.dn16:3.12.5: That was a really big earthquake!
translation_text.dn16:3.12.6: That was really a very big earthquake; awe-inspiring and hair-raising, and thunder cracked the sky!
translation_text.dn16:3.12.7: What’s the cause, what’s the reason for a great earthquake?”
translation_text.dn16:3.13.1: “Ānanda, there are these eight causes and reasons for a great earthquake.
translation_text.dn16:3.13.3: This great earth is established on water, the water is established on air, and the air stands in space. At a time when a great wind blows, it stirs the water, and the water stirs the earth.
translation_text.dn16:3.13.4: This is the first cause and reason for a great earthquake.
translation_text.dn16:3.14.1: Furthermore, there is an ascetic or brahmin with psychic power who has achieved mastery of the mind, or a god who is mighty and powerful. They’ve developed a limited perception of earth and a limitless perception of water. They make the earth shake and rock and tremble.
translation_text.dn16:3.14.2: This is the second cause and reason for a great earthquake.
translation_text.dn16:3.15.1: Furthermore, when the being intent on awakening passes away from the host of joyful gods, he’s conceived in his mother’s belly, mindful and aware. Then the earth shakes and rocks and trembles.
translation_text.dn16:3.15.2: This is the third cause and reason for a great earthquake.
translation_text.dn16:3.16.1: Furthermore, when the being intent on awakening comes out of his mother’s belly mindful and aware, the earth shakes and rocks and trembles.
translation_text.dn16:3.16.2: This is the fourth cause and reason for a great earthquake.
translation_text.dn16:3.17.1: Furthermore, when the Realized One awakens to the supreme perfect awakening, the earth shakes and rocks and trembles.
translation_text.dn16:3.17.2: This is the fifth cause and reason for a great earthquake.
translation_text.dn16:3.18.1: Furthermore, when the Realized One rolls forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma, the earth shakes and rocks and trembles.
translation_text.dn16:3.18.2: This is the sixth cause and reason for a great earthquake.
translation_text.dn16:3.19.1: Furthermore, when the Realized One, mindful and aware, surrenders the life force, the earth shakes and rocks and trembles.
translation_text.dn16:3.19.2: This is the seventh cause and reason for a great earthquake.
translation_text.dn16:3.20.1: Furthermore, when the Realized One becomes fully extinguished in the element of extinguishment with no residue, the earth shakes and rocks and trembles.
translation_text.dn16:3.20.2: This is the eighth cause and reason for a great earthquake.
translation_text.dn16:3.20.3: These are the eight causes and reasons for a great earthquake.
translation_text.dn16:3.21.1: There are, Ānanda, these eight assemblies.
translation_text.dn16:3.21.3: The assemblies of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, and ascetics. An assembly of the gods of the four great kings. An assembly of the gods of the thirty-three. An assembly of Māras. An assembly of divinities.
translation_text.dn16:3.22.1: I recall having approached an assembly of hundreds of aristocrats.
translation_text.dn16:3.22.2: There I used to sit with them, converse, and engage in discussion.
translation_text.dn16:3.22.3: And my appearance and voice became just like theirs.
translation_text.dn16:3.22.4: I educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired them with a Dhamma talk.
translation_text.dn16:3.22.5: But when I spoke they didn’t know:
translation_text.dn16:3.22.6: ‘Who is this that speaks? Is it a god or a human?’
translation_text.dn16:3.22.7: And when my Dhamma talk was finished I vanished.
translation_text.dn16:3.22.8: But when I vanished they didn’t know:
translation_text.dn16:3.22.9: ‘Who was that who vanished? Was it a god or a human?’
translation_text.dn16:3.23.1: I recall having approached an assembly of hundreds of brahmins …
translation_text.dn16:3.23.4: the gods of the four great kings …
translation_text.dn16:3.23.8: There too I used to sit with them, converse, and engage in discussion.
translation_text.dn16:3.23.9: And my appearance and voice became just like theirs.
translation_text.dn16:3.23.11: I educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired them with a Dhamma talk.
translation_text.dn16:3.23.12: But when I spoke they didn’t know:
translation_text.dn16:3.23.13: ‘Who is this that speaks? Is it a god or a human?’
translation_text.dn16:3.23.14: And when my Dhamma talk was finished I vanished.
translation_text.dn16:3.23.15: But when I vanished they didn’t know:
translation_text.dn16:3.23.16: ‘Who was that who vanished? Was it a god or a human?’
translation_text.dn16:3.24.1: Ānanda, there are these eight dimensions of mastery.
translation_text.dn16:3.25.1: Perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limited, both pretty and ugly.
translation_text.dn16:3.25.2: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.dn16:3.25.3: This is the first dimension of mastery.
translation_text.dn16:3.26.1: Perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limitless, both pretty and ugly.
translation_text.dn16:3.26.2: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.dn16:3.26.3: This is the second dimension of mastery.
translation_text.dn16:3.27.1: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limited, both pretty and ugly.
translation_text.dn16:3.27.2: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.dn16:3.27.3: This is the third dimension of mastery.
translation_text.dn16:3.28.1: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limitless, both pretty and ugly.
translation_text.dn16:3.28.2: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.dn16:3.28.3: This is the fourth dimension of mastery.
translation_text.dn16:3.29.1: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are blue, with blue color and blue appearance.
translation_text.dn16:3.29.2: They’re like a flax flower that’s blue, with blue color and blue appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, blue, with blue color and blue appearance.
translation_text.dn16:3.29.3: In the same way, not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, blue, with blue color and blue appearance.
translation_text.dn16:3.29.4: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.dn16:3.29.5: This is the fifth dimension of mastery.
translation_text.dn16:3.30.1: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance.
translation_text.dn16:3.30.2: They’re like a champak flower that’s yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance.
translation_text.dn16:3.30.3: In the same way, not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance.
translation_text.dn16:3.30.4: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.dn16:3.30.5: This is the sixth dimension of mastery.
translation_text.dn16:3.31.1: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are red, with red color and red appearance.
translation_text.dn16:3.31.2: They’re like a scarlet mallow flower that’s red, with red color and red appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, red, with red color and red appearance.
translation_text.dn16:3.31.3: In the same way, not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are red, with red color and red appearance.
translation_text.dn16:3.31.4: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.dn16:3.31.5: This is the seventh dimension of mastery.
translation_text.dn16:3.32.1: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are white, with white color and white appearance.
translation_text.dn16:3.32.2: They’re like the morning star that’s white, with white color and white appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, white, with white color and white appearance.
translation_text.dn16:3.32.3: In the same way, not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are white, with white color and white appearance.
translation_text.dn16:3.32.4: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.dn16:3.32.5: This is the eighth dimension of mastery.
translation_text.dn16:3.32.6: These are the eight dimensions of mastery.
translation_text.dn16:3.33.1: Ānanda, there are these eight liberations.
translation_text.dn16:3.33.3: Having physical form, they see forms.
translation_text.dn16:3.33.5: Not perceiving form internally, they see forms externally.
translation_text.dn16:3.33.9: Going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space.
translation_text.dn16:3.33.11: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness.
translation_text.dn16:3.33.13: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness.
translation_text.dn16:3.33.15: Going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, they enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
translation_text.dn16:3.33.17: Going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, they enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling.
translation_text.dn16:3.34.1: Ānanda, this one time, when I was first awakened, I was staying in Uruvelā at the goatherd’s banyan tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.
translation_text.dn16:3.34.2: Then Māra the wicked approached me, stood to one side, and said:
translation_text.dn16:3.34.3: ‘Sir, may the Blessed One now be fully extinguished! May the Holy One now be fully extinguished! Now is the time for the full extinguishment of the Buddha.’
translation_text.dn16:3.34.4: When he had spoken, I said to Māra:
translation_text.dn16:3.35.1: ‘Wicked One, I shall not be fully extinguished until I have monk disciples …
translation_text.dn16:3.35.4: laywoman disciples who are competent, educated, assured, learned.
translation_text.dn16:3.35.5: I shall not be fully extinguished until my spiritual path is successful and prosperous, extensive, popular, widespread, and well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans.’
translation_text.dn16:3.36.1: Today, just now at the Cāpāla Shrine Māra the Wicked approached me once more with the same request, reminding me of my former statement, and saying that those conditions had been fulfilled.
translation_text.dn16:3.37.1: When he had spoken, I said to Māra:
translation_text.dn16:3.37.2: ‘Relax, Wicked One. The full extinguishment of the Realized One will be soon.
translation_text.dn16:3.37.3: Three months from now the Realized One will be fully extinguished.’
translation_text.dn16:3.37.4: So today, just now at the Cāpāla Shrine, mindful and aware, I surrendered the life force.”
translation_text.dn16:3.38.1: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn16:3.38.2: “Sir, may the Blessed One please remain for the proper lifespan! May the Holy One please remain for the proper lifespan! That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.”
translation_text.dn16:3.38.4: Do not beg the Realized One. Now is not the time to beg the Realized One.”
translation_text.dn16:3.39.2: For a third time, Ānanda said to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn16:3.39.3: “Sir, may the Blessed One please remain for the proper lifespan! May the Holy One please remain for the proper lifespan! That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.”
translation_text.dn16:3.39.4: “Ānanda, do you have faith in the Realized One’s awakening?”
translation_text.dn16:3.39.6: “So why then do you keep pressing me up to the third time?”
translation_text.dn16:3.40.1: “Sir, I have heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
translation_text.dn16:3.40.2: ‘Whoever has developed and cultivated the four bases of psychic power—made them a vehicle and a basis, kept them up, consolidated them, and properly implemented them—may, if they wish, live for the proper lifespan or what’s left of it.
translation_text.dn16:3.40.3: The Realized One has developed and cultivated the four bases of psychic power, made them a vehicle and a basis, kept them up, consolidated them, and properly implemented them. If he wished, the Realized One could live for the proper lifespan or what’s left of it.’”
translation_text.dn16:3.40.6: “Therefore, Ānanda, the misdeed is yours alone, the mistake is yours alone. For even though the Realized One dropped such an obvious hint, such a clear sign, you didn’t beg me to remain for the proper lifespan, or what’s left of it.
translation_text.dn16:3.40.8: If you had begged me, I would have turned you down twice, but consented on the third time.
translation_text.dn16:3.40.9: Therefore, Ānanda, the misdeed is yours alone, the mistake is yours alone.
translation_text.dn16:3.41.1: Ānanda, this one time I was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
translation_text.dn16:3.41.3: ‘Ānanda, Rājagaha is lovely, and so is the Vulture’s Peak.
translation_text.dn16:3.41.4: Whoever has developed and cultivated the four bases of psychic power—made them a vehicle and a basis, kept them up, consolidated them, and properly implemented them—may, if they wish, live for the proper lifespan or what’s left of it.
translation_text.dn16:3.41.5: The Realized One has developed and cultivated the four bases of psychic power, made them a vehicle and a basis, kept them up, consolidated them, and properly implemented them. If he wished, the Realized One could live for the proper lifespan or what’s left of it.’
translation_text.dn16:3.41.6: But you didn’t get it, even though I dropped such an obvious hint, such a clear sign. You didn’t beg me to remain for the proper lifespan, or what’s left of it.
translation_text.dn16:3.41.8: If you had begged me, I would have turned you down twice, but consented on the third time.
translation_text.dn16:3.41.9: Therefore, Ānanda, the misdeed is yours alone, the mistake is yours alone.
translation_text.dn16:3.42.1: Ānanda, this one time I was staying right there near Rājagaha, at the Gotama banyan tree …
translation_text.dn16:3.42.3: in the Sattapaṇṇi cave on the slopes of Vebhāra …
translation_text.dn16:3.42.4: at the Black Rock on the slopes of Isigili …
translation_text.dn16:3.42.5: in the Cool Grove, under the Snake’s Hood Grotto …
translation_text.dn16:3.42.7: in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground …
translation_text.dn16:3.43.1: And in each place I said to you:
translation_text.dn16:3.43.2: ‘Ānanda, Rājagaha is lovely, and so are all these places. …
translation_text.dn16:3.44.2: If he wished, the Realized One could live for the proper lifespan or what’s left of it.’
translation_text.dn16:3.44.3: But you didn’t get it, even though I dropped such an obvious hint, such a clear sign. You didn’t beg me to remain for the proper lifespan, or what’s left of it.
translation_text.dn16:3.45.1: Ānanda, this one time I was staying right here near Vesālī, at the Udena Shrine …
translation_text.dn16:3.47.1: and just now, today at the Cāpāla Shrine. There I said to you:
translation_text.dn16:3.47.2: ‘Ānanda, Vesālī is lovely. And the Udena, Gotamaka, Seven Maidens, Many Sons, Sārandada, and Cāpāla Shrines are all lovely.
translation_text.dn16:3.47.3: Whoever has developed and cultivated the four bases of psychic power—made them a vehicle and a basis, kept them up, consolidated them, and properly implemented them—may, if they wish, live for the proper lifespan or what’s left of it.
translation_text.dn16:3.47.4: The Realized One has developed and cultivated the four bases of psychic power, made them a vehicle and a basis, kept them up, consolidated them, and properly implemented them. If he wished, the Realized One could live for the proper lifespan or what’s left of it.’
translation_text.dn16:3.47.5: But you didn’t get it, even though I dropped such an obvious hint, such a clear sign. You didn’t beg me to remain for the proper lifespan, or what’s left of it, saying:
translation_text.dn16:3.47.6: ‘Sir, may the Blessed One please remain for the proper lifespan! May the Holy One please remain for the proper lifespan! That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.’
translation_text.dn16:3.47.7: If you had begged me, I would have turned you down twice, but consented on the third time.
translation_text.dn16:3.47.8: Therefore, Ānanda, the misdeed is yours alone, the mistake is yours alone.
translation_text.dn16:3.48.1: Did I not prepare for this when I explained that
translation_text.dn16:3.48.2: we must be parted and separated from all we hold dear and beloved?
translation_text.dn16:3.48.3: How could it possibly be so that what is born, created, conditioned, and liable to wear out should not wear out?
translation_text.dn16:3.48.4: The Realized One has discarded, eliminated, released, given up, relinquished, and surrendered the life force. He has categorically stated:
translation_text.dn16:3.48.5: ‘The full extinguishment of the Realized One will be soon.
translation_text.dn16:3.48.6: Three months from now the Realized One will be fully extinguished.’
translation_text.dn16:3.48.7: It’s not possible for the Realized One, for the sake of life, to take back the life force once it has been given up like that.
translation_text.dn16:3.48.8: Come, Ānanda, let’s go to the Great Wood, the hall with the peaked roof.”
translation_text.dn16:3.49.1: So the Buddha went with Ānanda to the hall with the peaked roof, and said to him,
translation_text.dn16:3.49.2: “Go, Ānanda, gather all the mendicants staying in the vicinity of Vesālī together in the assembly hall.”
translation_text.dn16:3.49.3: “Yes, sir,” replied Ānanda. He did what the Buddha asked, went up to him, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him,
translation_text.dn16:3.49.4: “Sir, the mendicant Saṅgha has assembled. Please, sir, go at your convenience.”
translation_text.dn16:3.50.1: Then the Buddha went to the assembly hall, where he sat on the seat spread out
translation_text.dn16:3.50.3: “So, mendicants, having carefully memorized those things I have taught you from my direct knowledge, you should cultivate, develop, and make much of them so that this spiritual practice may last for a long time. That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.
translation_text.dn16:3.50.4: And what are those things I have taught from my direct knowledge?
translation_text.dn16:3.50.5: They are: the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, the four right efforts, the four bases of psychic power, the five faculties, the five powers, the seven awakening factors, and the noble eightfold path.
translation_text.dn16:3.51.1: These are the things I have taught from my direct knowledge. Having carefully memorized them, you should cultivate, develop, and make much of them so that this spiritual practice may last for a long time. That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.”
translation_text.dn16:3.51.2: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:
translation_text.dn16:3.51.3: “Come now, mendicants, I say to you all:
translation_text.dn16:3.51.5: The full extinguishment of the Realized One will be soon.
translation_text.dn16:3.51.6: Three months from now the Realized One will be fully extinguished.”
translation_text.dn16:3.51.7: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.dn16:3.51.8: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
translation_text.dn16:3.51.10: and little of my life is left.
translation_text.dn16:3.51.11: Having given it up, I’ll depart;
translation_text.dn16:3.51.12: I’ve made a refuge for myself.
translation_text.dn16:3.51.16: take good care of your minds.

translation_text.dn16:4.1.1: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Vesālī for alms.
translation_text.dn16:4.1.2: Then, after the meal, on his return from almsround, he turned to gaze back at Vesālī, the way that elephants do. He said to Venerable Ānanda:
translation_text.dn16:4.1.3: “Ānanda, this will be the last time the Realized One sees Vesālī.
translation_text.dn16:4.1.4: Come, Ānanda, let’s go to Wares Village.”
translation_text.dn16:4.2.1: Then the Buddha together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants arrived at Wares Village,
translation_text.dn16:4.2.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
translation_text.dn16:4.2.4: “Mendicants, due to not understanding and not penetrating four things, both you and I have wandered and transmigrated for such a very long time.
translation_text.dn16:4.2.10: These noble ethics, immersion, wisdom, and freedom have been understood and comprehended. Craving for continued existence has been cut off; the leash to existence is ended; now there’ll be no more future lives.”
translation_text.dn16:4.3.1: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.dn16:4.3.2: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
translation_text.dn16:4.3.7: And so the Buddha, having insight,
translation_text.dn16:4.3.8: explained this teaching to the mendicants.
translation_text.dn16:4.3.9: The teacher made an end of suffering,
translation_text.dn16:4.3.10: seeing clearly, he is fully quenched.”

translation_text.dn16:4.4.2: “Such is ethics, such is immersion, such is wisdom.

translation_text.dn16:4.4.4: When wisdom is imbued with immersion it’s very fruitful and beneficial.

translation_text.dn16:4.8.3: this is the teaching, this is the training, this is the Teacher’s instruction.’
translation_text.dn16:4.8.4: You should neither approve nor reject that mendicant’s statement.

translation_text.dn16:4.12.3: When immersion is imbued with ethics it’s very fruitful and beneficial.
