translation_text.dn16:4.13.1: When the Buddha had stayed in Bhoga City as long as he pleased, he addressed Ānanda,
translation_text.dn16:4.13.4: Then the Buddha together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants arrived at Pāvā,
translation_text.dn16:4.13.5: where he stayed in Cunda the smith’s mango grove.
translation_text.dn16:4.14.1: Cunda heard that the Buddha had arrived and was staying in his mango grove.
translation_text.dn16:4.14.2: Then he went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.
translation_text.dn16:4.14.3: The Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired him with a Dhamma talk.
translation_text.dn16:4.14.4: Then Cunda said to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn16:4.15.1: “Sir, may the Buddha together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me.”
translation_text.dn16:4.16.1: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, Cunda got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
translation_text.dn16:4.17.1: And when the night had passed Cunda had delicious fresh and cooked foods prepared in his own home, and plenty of pork on the turn. Then he had the Buddha informed of the time, saying,
translation_text.dn16:4.17.2: “Sir, it’s time. The meal is ready.”
translation_text.dn16:4.18.1: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the home of Cunda together with the mendicant Saṅgha, where he sat on the seat spread out
translation_text.dn16:4.18.3: “Cunda, please serve me with the pork on the turn that you’ve prepared.
translation_text.dn16:4.18.4: And serve the mendicant Saṅgha with the other foods.”
translation_text.dn16:4.18.5: “Yes, sir,” replied Cunda, and did as he was asked.
translation_text.dn16:4.19.2: “Cunda, any pork on the turn that’s left over, you should bury it in a pit.
translation_text.dn16:4.19.3: I don’t see anyone in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—who could properly digest it except for the Realized One.”
translation_text.dn16:4.19.4: “Yes, sir,” replied Cunda. He did as he was asked, then came back to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.
translation_text.dn16:4.19.5: Then the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired him with a Dhamma talk, after which he got up from his seat and left.
translation_text.dn16:4.20.1: After the Buddha had eaten Cunda’s meal, he fell severely ill with bloody dysentery, struck by dreadful pains, close to death.
translation_text.dn16:4.20.2: But he endured unbothered, with mindfulness and situational awareness.
translation_text.dn16:4.20.7: the meal of Cunda the smith,
translation_text.dn16:4.20.8: the attentive one fell severely ill,
translation_text.dn16:4.20.10: A severe sickness struck the Teacher
translation_text.dn16:4.20.11: who had eaten the pork on the turn.
translation_text.dn16:4.20.12: While still purging the Buddha said:
translation_text.dn16:4.20.13: “I’ll go to the citadel of Kusinārā.”
translation_text.dn16:4.21.1: Then the Buddha left the road and went to the root of a certain tree, where he addressed Ānanda,
translation_text.dn16:4.21.2: “Please, Ānanda, fold my outer robe in four and spread it out for me. I am tired and will sit down.”
translation_text.dn16:4.21.3: “Yes, sir,” replied Ānanda, and did as he was asked.
translation_text.dn16:4.21.4: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out.
translation_text.dn16:4.22.1: When he was seated he said to Venerable Ānanda,
translation_text.dn16:4.22.2: “Please, Ānanda, fetch me some water. I am thirsty and will drink.”
translation_text.dn16:4.22.3: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn16:4.22.4: “Sir, just now around five hundred carts have passed by. The shallow water has been churned up by their wheels, and it flows cloudy and murky.
translation_text.dn16:4.22.5: The Kakudhā river is not far away, with clear, sweet, cool water, clean, with smooth banks, delightful.
translation_text.dn16:4.22.6: There the Buddha can drink and cool his limbs.”
translation_text.dn16:4.23.1: For a second time, the Buddha asked Ānanda for a drink,
translation_text.dn16:4.23.3: and for a second time Ānanda suggested going to the Kakudhā river.
translation_text.dn16:4.24.1: And for a third time, the Buddha said to Ānanda,
translation_text.dn16:4.24.2: “Please, Ānanda, fetch me some water. I am thirsty and will drink.”
translation_text.dn16:4.24.3: “Yes, sir,” replied Ānanda. Taking his bowl he went to the river.
translation_text.dn16:4.24.4: Now, though the shallow water in that creek had been churned up by wheels, and flowed cloudy and murky, when Ānanda approached it flowed transparent, clear, and unclouded.
translation_text.dn16:4.25.2: “Oh lord, how incredible, how amazing! The Realized One has such psychic power and might!
translation_text.dn16:4.25.3: For though the shallow water in that creek had been churned up by wheels, and flowed cloudy and murky, when I approached it flowed transparent, clear, and unclouded.”
translation_text.dn16:4.25.4: Gathering a bowl of drinking water he went back to the Buddha, and said to him,
translation_text.dn16:4.25.5: “It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing! The Realized One has such psychic power and might!
translation_text.dn16:4.25.6: Just now, though the shallow water in that creek had been churned up by wheels, and flowed cloudy and murky, when I approached it flowed transparent, clear, and unclouded.
translation_text.dn16:4.25.7: Drink the water, Blessed One! Drink the water, Holy One!”
translation_text.dn16:4.25.8: So the Buddha drank the water.
translation_text.dn16:4.26.1: Now at that time Pukkusa the Malla, a disciple of Āḷāra Kālāma, was traveling along the road from Kusinārā to Pāvā.
translation_text.dn16:4.26.2: He saw the Buddha sitting at the root of a certain tree.
translation_text.dn16:4.26.3: He went up to him, bowed, sat down to one side, and said,
translation_text.dn16:4.26.4: “It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing! Those who have gone forth remain in such peaceful meditations.
translation_text.dn16:4.27.1: Once it so happened that Āḷāra Kālāma, while traveling along a road, left the road and sat at the root of a nearby tree for the day’s meditation.
translation_text.dn16:4.27.2: Then around five hundred carts passed by right beside Āḷāra Kālāma.
translation_text.dn16:4.27.3: Then a certain person coming behind those carts went up to Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him:
translation_text.dn16:4.27.4: ‘Sir, didn’t you see the five hundred carts pass by?’
translation_text.dn16:4.27.6: ‘But sir, didn’t you hear a sound?’
translation_text.dn16:4.27.7: ‘No, friend, I didn’t hear a sound.’
translation_text.dn16:4.27.12: ‘So, sir, while conscious and awake you neither saw nor heard a sound as five hundred carts passed by right beside you?
translation_text.dn16:4.27.13: Why sir, even your outer robe is covered with dust!’
translation_text.dn16:4.27.16: ‘Oh lord, how incredible, how amazing! Those who have gone forth remain in such peaceful meditations,
translation_text.dn16:4.27.17: in that, while conscious and awake he neither saw nor heard a sound as five hundred carts passed by right next to him.’
translation_text.dn16:4.27.18: And after declaring his lofty confidence in Āḷāra Kālāma, he left.”
translation_text.dn16:4.28.2: Which is harder and more challenging to do while conscious and awake:
translation_text.dn16:4.28.3: to neither see nor hear a sound as five hundred carts pass by right next to you?
translation_text.dn16:4.28.4: Or to neither see nor hear a sound as the heavens are raining and pouring, lightning’s flashing, and thunder’s cracking?”
translation_text.dn16:4.29.1: “What do five hundred carts matter, or six hundred, or seven hundred, or eight hundred, or nine hundred, or a thousand, or even a hundred thousand carts?
translation_text.dn16:4.29.2: It’s far harder and more challenging to neither see nor hear a sound as the heavens are raining and pouring, lightning’s flashing, and thunder’s cracking!”
translation_text.dn16:4.30.1: “This one time, Pukkusa, I was staying near Ātumā in a threshing-hut.
translation_text.dn16:4.30.2: At that time the heavens were raining and pouring, lightning was flashing, and thunder was cracking. And not far from the threshing-hut two farmers who were brothers were killed, as well as four oxen.
translation_text.dn16:4.30.3: Then a large crowd came from Ātumā to the place where that happened.
translation_text.dn16:4.31.1: Now at that time I came out of the threshing-hut and was walking mindfully in the open near the door of the hut.
translation_text.dn16:4.31.2: Then having left that crowd, a certain person approached me, bowed, and stood to one side. I said to them,
translation_text.dn16:4.32.2: ‘Just now, sir, the heavens were raining and pouring, lightning was flashing, and thunder was cracking. And two farmers who were brothers were killed, as well as four oxen.
translation_text.dn16:4.32.8: ‘But sir, didn’t you hear a sound?’
translation_text.dn16:4.32.9: ‘No, friend, I didn’t hear a sound.’
translation_text.dn16:4.32.14: ‘So, sir, while conscious and awake you neither saw nor heard a sound as the heavens were raining and pouring, lightning was flashing, and thunder was cracking?’
translation_text.dn16:4.33.2: ‘Oh lord, how incredible, how amazing! Those who have gone forth remain in such peaceful meditations,
translation_text.dn16:4.33.3: in that, while conscious and awake he neither saw nor heard a sound as the heavens were raining and pouring, lightning was flashing, and thunder was cracking.’
translation_text.dn16:4.33.4: And after declaring their lofty confidence in me, they bowed and respectfully circled me, keeping me on their right, before leaving.”
translation_text.dn16:4.34.1: When he said this, Pukkusa said to him,
translation_text.dn16:4.34.2: “Any confidence I had in Āḷāra Kālāma I whisk away as in a strong wind, or glide away as down a swift stream.
translation_text.dn16:4.34.4: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.
translation_text.dn16:4.34.5: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.dn16:4.34.6: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
translation_text.dn16:4.35.1: Then Pukkusa addressed a certain man,
translation_text.dn16:4.35.2: “Please, my man, fetch a pair of ready to wear garments the color of mountain gold.”
translation_text.dn16:4.35.3: “Yes, sir,” replied that man, and did as he was asked.
translation_text.dn16:4.35.4: Then Pukkusa brought the garments to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn16:4.35.5: “Sir, please accept this pair of ready to wear garments the color of mountain gold from me out of sympathy.”
translation_text.dn16:4.35.6: “Well then, Pukkusa, clothe me in one, and Ānanda in the other.”
translation_text.dn16:4.35.7: “Yes, sir,” replied Pukkusa, and did so.
translation_text.dn16:4.36.1: Then the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired Pukkusa the Malla with a Dhamma talk,
translation_text.dn16:4.36.2: after which he got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha before leaving.
translation_text.dn16:4.37.1: Then, not long after Pukkusa had left, Ānanda placed the pair of garments the color of mountain gold by the Buddha’s body.
translation_text.dn16:4.37.2: But when placed by the Buddha’s body they seemed to lose their shine.
translation_text.dn16:4.37.3: Then Ānanda said to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn16:4.37.4: “It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing, how pure and bright is the color of the Realized One’s skin.
translation_text.dn16:4.37.5: When this pair of ready to wear garments the color of mountain gold is placed by the Buddha’s body they seem to lose their sheen.”
translation_text.dn16:4.37.6: “That’s so true, Ānanda, that’s so true! There are two times when the color of the Realized One’s skin becomes extra pure and bright.
translation_text.dn16:4.38.2: The night when a Realized One awakens to the supreme perfect awakening; and the night he becomes fully extinguished in the element of extinguishment with no residue.
translation_text.dn16:4.38.3: These are the are two times when the color of the Realized One’s skin becomes extra pure and bright.
translation_text.dn16:4.38.4: Today, Ānanda, in the last watch of the night, between a pair of sal trees in the sal forest of the Mallas at Upavattana near Kusinārā, shall be the Realized One’s full extinguishment.
translation_text.dn16:4.38.5: Come, Ānanda, let’s go to the Kakudhā River.”
translation_text.dn16:4.38.7: A pair of garments the color of mountain gold
translation_text.dn16:4.38.9: when the teacher was clothed with them,
translation_text.dn16:4.38.10: his snow gold skin glowed bright.
translation_text.dn16:4.39.1: Then the Buddha together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants went to the Kakudhā River. He plunged into the river and bathed and drank. And when he had emerged, he went to the mango grove,
translation_text.dn16:4.39.3: “Please, Cundaka, fold my outer robe in four and spread it out for me. I am tired and will lie down.”
translation_text.dn16:4.40.1: “Yes, sir,” replied Cundaka, and did as he was asked.
translation_text.dn16:4.40.2: And then the Buddha laid down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware, and focused on the time of getting up.
translation_text.dn16:4.40.3: But Cundaka sat down right there in front of the Buddha.
translation_text.dn16:4.41.2: whose water was transparent, sweet, and clear,
translation_text.dn16:4.41.3: the Teacher, being tired, plunged in,
translation_text.dn16:4.41.4: the Realized One, without compare in the world.
translation_text.dn16:4.41.5: And after bathing and drinking the Teacher emerged.
translation_text.dn16:4.41.6: Before the group of mendicants, in the middle, <j>the Buddha,
translation_text.dn16:4.41.7: the Teacher <j>who rolled forth the present dispensation,
translation_text.dn16:4.41.8: the great seer went to the mango grove.
translation_text.dn16:4.41.9: He addressed the mendicant named Cundaka:
translation_text.dn16:4.41.10: “Spread out my folded robe so I can lie down.”
translation_text.dn16:4.41.12: who quickly spread the folded robe.
translation_text.dn16:4.41.13: The Teacher lay down so tired,
translation_text.dn16:4.41.14: while Cunda sat there before him.
translation_text.dn16:4.42.1: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Ānanda:
translation_text.dn16:4.42.2: “Now it may happen, Ānanda, that someone may give rise to regret in Cunda the smith:
translation_text.dn16:4.42.3: ‘It’s your loss, respected Cunda, it’s your misfortune, in that the Realized One was fully quenched after eating his last almsmeal from you.’
translation_text.dn16:4.42.4: You should dispel remorse in Cunda the smith like this:
translation_text.dn16:4.42.5: ‘You’re fortunate, respected Cunda, you’re so very fortunate,
translation_text.dn16:4.42.6: in that the Realized One was fully quenched after eating his last almsmeal from you.
translation_text.dn16:4.42.7: I have heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha.
translation_text.dn16:4.42.8: There are two almsmeal offerings that have identical fruit and result, and are more fruitful and beneficial than other almsmeal offerings.
translation_text.dn16:4.42.10: The almsmeal after eating which a Realized One awakens to the supreme perfect awakening; and the almsmeal after eating which he becomes fully extinguished in the element of extinguishment with no residue.
translation_text.dn16:4.42.11: These two almsmeal offerings have identical fruit and result, and are more fruitful and beneficial than other almsmeal offerings.
translation_text.dn16:4.42.12: You’ve accumulated a deed that leads to long life, beauty, happiness, fame, heaven, and sovereignty.’
translation_text.dn16:4.42.13: That’s how you should dispel remorse in Cunda the smith.”
translation_text.dn16:4.43.1: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
translation_text.dn16:4.43.3: enmity doesn’t build up when you have self-control.
translation_text.dn16:4.43.4: A skillful person gives up bad things—
translation_text.dn16:4.43.5: with the end of greed, hate, and delusion, <j>they’re quenched.”
translation_text.dn16:5.1.1: Then the Buddha said to Ānanda,
translation_text.dn16:5.1.2: “Come, Ānanda, let’s go to the far shore of the Golden River, and on to the sal forest of the Mallas at Upavattana near Kusinārā.”
translation_text.dn16:5.1.4: And that’s where they went. Then the Buddha addressed Ānanda,
translation_text.dn16:5.1.5: “Please, Ānanda, set up a cot for me between the twin sal trees, with my head to the north. I am tired and will lie down.”
translation_text.dn16:5.1.6: “Yes, sir,” replied Ānanda, and did as he was asked.
translation_text.dn16:5.1.7: And then the Buddha laid down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware.
translation_text.dn16:5.2.1: Now at that time the twin sal trees were in full blossom with flowers out of season.
translation_text.dn16:5.2.2: They sprinkled and bestrewed the Realized One’s body in honor of the Realized One.
translation_text.dn16:5.2.3: And the flowers of the heavenly Flame Tree fell from the sky, and they too sprinkled and bestrewed the Realized One’s body in honor of the Realized One.
translation_text.dn16:5.2.4: And heavenly sandalwood powder fell from the sky, and it too sprinkled and bestrewed the Realized One’s body in honor of the Realized One.
translation_text.dn16:5.2.5: And heavenly music played in midair in honor of the Realized One.
translation_text.dn16:5.2.6: And heavenly choirs sang in midair in honor of the Realized One.
translation_text.dn16:5.3.1: Then the Buddha pointed out to Ānanda what was happening, adding:
translation_text.dn16:5.3.8: “That’s not the full extent of how the Realized One is honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed.
translation_text.dn16:5.3.9: Any monk or nun or male or female lay follower who practices in line with the teaching, practicing properly, living in line with the teaching—they honor, respect, revere, venerate, and esteem the Realized One with the highest honor.
translation_text.dn16:5.3.10: So Ānanda, you should train like this: ‘We shall practice in line with the teaching, practicing properly, living in line with the teaching.’”
translation_text.dn16:5.4.1: Now at that time Venerable Upavāṇa was standing in front of the Buddha fanning him.
translation_text.dn16:5.4.2: Then the Buddha made him move,
translation_text.dn16:5.4.3: “Move over, mendicant, don’t stand in front of me.”
translation_text.dn16:5.4.5: “This Venerable Upavāṇa has been the Buddha’s attendant for a long time, close to him, living in his presence.
translation_text.dn16:5.4.6: Yet in his final hour the Buddha makes him move, saying:
translation_text.dn16:5.4.7: ‘Move over, mendicant, don’t stand in front of me.’
translation_text.dn16:5.4.8: What is the cause, what is the reason for this?”
translation_text.dn16:5.5.1: Then Ānanda said to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn16:5.5.2: “This Venerable Upavāṇa has been the Buddha’s attendant for a long time, close to him, living in his presence.
translation_text.dn16:5.5.3: Yet in his final hour the Buddha makes him move, saying:
translation_text.dn16:5.5.4: ‘Move over, mendicant, don’t stand in front of me.’
translation_text.dn16:5.5.5: What is the cause, sir, what is the reason for this?”
translation_text.dn16:5.5.7: “Most of the deities from ten solar systems have gathered to see the Realized One.
translation_text.dn16:5.5.8: For twelve leagues all around this sal grove there’s no spot, not even a fraction of a hair’s tip, that’s not crowded full of illustrious deities.
translation_text.dn16:5.5.10: ‘We’ve come such a long way to see the Realized One!
translation_text.dn16:5.5.11: Only rarely do Realized Ones arise in the world, perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas.
translation_text.dn16:5.5.12: This very day, in the last watch of the night, the Realized One will be fully extinguished.
translation_text.dn16:5.5.13: And this illustrious mendicant is standing in front of the Buddha blocking the view. We won’t get to see the Realized One in his final hour!’”
translation_text.dn16:5.6.1: “But sir, what kind of deities are you thinking of?”
translation_text.dn16:5.6.2: “There are, Ānanda, deities—both in space and on the earth—who are aware of the earth. With hair disheveled and arms raised, they fall down like their feet were chopped off, rolling back and forth, lamenting:
translation_text.dn16:5.6.3: ‘Too soon the Blessed One will be fully extinguished! Too soon the Holy One will be fully extinguished! Too soon the Eye of the World will vanish!’
translation_text.dn16:5.6.6: But the deities who are free of desire endure, mindful and aware, thinking:
translation_text.dn16:5.6.7: ‘Conditions are impermanent. How could it possibly be otherwise?’”
translation_text.dn16:5.7.1: “Previously, sir, when mendicants had completed the rainy season residence in various districts they came to see the Realized One.
translation_text.dn16:5.7.2: We got to see the esteemed mendicants, and to pay homage to them.
translation_text.dn16:5.7.3: But when the Buddha has passed, we won’t get to see the esteemed mendicants or to pay homage to them.”
translation_text.dn16:5.8.1: “Ānanda, a faithful gentleman should go to see these four inspiring places.
translation_text.dn16:5.8.3: Thinking: ‘Here the Realized One was born!’—that is an inspiring place.
translation_text.dn16:5.8.4: Thinking: ‘Here the Realized One became awakened as a supreme fully awakened Buddha!’—that is an inspiring place.
translation_text.dn16:5.8.5: Thinking: ‘Here the supreme Wheel of Dhamma was rolled forth by the Realized One!’—that is an inspiring place.
translation_text.dn16:5.8.6: Thinking: ‘Here the Realized One was fully quenched in the element of extinguishment with no residue!’—that is an inspiring place.
translation_text.dn16:5.8.7: These are the four inspiring places that a faithful gentleman should go to see.
translation_text.dn16:5.8.8: Faithful monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen will come, and think:
translation_text.dn16:5.8.9: ‘Here the Realized One was born!’ and ‘Here the Realized One became awakened as a supreme fully awakened Buddha!’ and ‘Here the supreme Wheel of Dhamma was rolled forth by the Realized One!’ and ‘Here the Realized One was fully quenched in the element of extinguishment with no residue!’
translation_text.dn16:5.8.10: Anyone who passes away while on pilgrimage to these shrines will, when their body breaks up, after death, be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.”
translation_text.dn16:5.9.1: “Sir, how do we proceed when it comes to ladies?”
translation_text.dn16:5.10.1: “Sir, how do we proceed when it comes to the Realized One’s corpse?”
translation_text.dn16:5.10.2: “Don’t get involved in the rites for venerating the Realized One’s corpse, Ānanda.
translation_text.dn16:5.10.3: Please, Ānanda, you must all strive and practice for your heart’s goal! Meditate diligent, keen, and resolute for your heart’s goal!
translation_text.dn16:5.10.4: There are astute aristocrats, brahmins, and householders who are devoted to the Realized One. They will perform the rites for venerating the Realized One’s corpse.”
translation_text.dn16:5.11.1: “But sir, how to proceed when it comes to the Realized One’s corpse?”
translation_text.dn16:5.11.2: “Proceed in the same way as they do for the corpse of a wheel-turning monarch.”
translation_text.dn16:5.11.3: “But how do they proceed with a wheel-turning monarch’s corpse?”
translation_text.dn16:5.11.4: “They wrap a wheel-turning monarch’s corpse with unworn cloth, then with uncarded cotton, then again with unworn cloth.
translation_text.dn16:5.11.5: In this way they wrap the corpse with five hundred double-layers. Then they place it in an iron casket filled with oil and close it up with another casket. Then, having built a funeral pyre out of all kinds of aromatics, they cremate the corpse.
translation_text.dn16:5.11.6: They build a monument for the wheel-turning monarch at the crossroads.
translation_text.dn16:5.11.7: That’s how they proceed with a wheel-turning monarch’s corpse.
translation_text.dn16:5.11.8: Proceed in the same way with the Realized One’s corpse.
translation_text.dn16:5.11.9: A monument for the Realized One is to be built at the crossroads.
translation_text.dn16:5.11.10: When someone there lifts up garlands or fragrance or powder, or bows, or inspires confidence in their heart, that will be for their lasting welfare and happiness.
translation_text.dn16:5.12.1: Ānanda, these four are worthy of a monument.
translation_text.dn16:5.12.3: A Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha; an independent Buddha; a disciple of a Realized One; and a wheel-turning monarch.
translation_text.dn16:5.12.4: And for what reason is a Realized One worthy of a monument?
translation_text.dn16:5.12.5: So that many people will inspire confidence in their hearts, thinking: ‘This is the monument for that Blessed One, perfected and fully awakened!’
translation_text.dn16:5.12.6: And having done so, when their body breaks up, after death, they are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.dn16:5.12.7: It is for this reason that a Realized One is worthy of a monument.
translation_text.dn16:5.12.8: And for what reason is an independent Buddha worthy of a monument?
translation_text.dn16:5.12.9: So that many people will inspire confidence in their hearts, thinking: ‘This is the monument for that independent Buddha!’
translation_text.dn16:5.12.10: And having done so, when their body breaks up, after death, they are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.dn16:5.12.11: It is for this reason that an independent Buddha is worthy of a monument.
translation_text.dn16:5.12.12: And for what reason is a Realized One’s disciple worthy of a monument?
translation_text.dn16:5.12.13: So that many people will inspire confidence in their hearts, thinking: ‘This is the monument for that Blessed One’s disciple!’
translation_text.dn16:5.12.14: And having done so, when their body breaks up, after death, they are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.dn16:5.12.15: It is for this reason that a Realized One’s disciple is worthy of a monument.
translation_text.dn16:5.12.16: And for what reason is a wheel-turning monarch worthy of a monument?
translation_text.dn16:5.12.17: So that many people will inspire confidence in their hearts, thinking: ‘This is the monument for that just and principled king!’
translation_text.dn16:5.12.18: And having done so, when their body breaks up, after death, they are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.dn16:5.12.19: It is for this reason that a wheel-turning monarch is worthy of a monument.
translation_text.dn16:5.12.20: These four are worthy of a monument.”
translation_text.dn16:5.13.1: Then Venerable Ānanda entered a building, and stood there leaning against the door-jamb and crying,
translation_text.dn16:5.13.2: “Oh! I’m still only a trainee with work left to do; and my Teacher is about to be fully extinguished, he who is so kind to me!”
translation_text.dn16:5.13.3: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,
translation_text.dn16:5.13.5: “Sir, Ānanda has entered a dwelling, and stands there leaning against the door-jamb and crying:
translation_text.dn16:5.13.6: ‘Oh! I’m still only a trainee with work left to do; and my Teacher is about to be fully extinguished, he who is so kind to me!’”
translation_text.dn16:5.13.7: So the Buddha addressed one of the monks,
translation_text.dn16:5.13.8: “Please, monk, in my name tell Ānanda that
translation_text.dn16:5.13.10: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to Ānanda and said to him,
translation_text.dn16:5.14.1: “Yes, reverend,” Ānanda replied. He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:
translation_text.dn16:5.14.2: “Enough, Ānanda! Do not grieve, do not lament. Did I not prepare for this when I explained that
translation_text.dn16:5.14.3: we must be parted and separated from all we hold dear and beloved?
translation_text.dn16:5.14.4: How could it possibly be so that what is born, created, conditioned, and liable to wear out should not wear out, even the Realized One’s body?
translation_text.dn16:5.14.5: For a long time, Ānanda, you’ve treated the Realized One with deeds of body, speech, and mind that are loving, beneficial, pleasant, undivided, and limitless.
translation_text.dn16:5.14.6: You have done good deeds, Ānanda. Devote yourself to meditation, and you will soon be free of defilements.”
translation_text.dn16:5.15.1: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:
translation_text.dn16:5.15.2: “Those who were perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas in the past also had attendants, who at best were like Ānanda is for me.
translation_text.dn16:5.15.3: Those who will be perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas in the future will also have attendants, who at best will be like Ānanda is for me.
translation_text.dn16:5.15.6: He knows the time for monks, nuns, laymen, laywomen, king’s ministers, monastics of other religions and their disciples to visit the Realized One.
translation_text.dn16:5.16.1: There are these four incredible and amazing things about Ānanda.
translation_text.dn16:5.16.3: If an assembly of monks goes to see Ānanda, they’re uplifted by seeing him
translation_text.dn16:5.16.4: and uplifted by hearing him speak.
translation_text.dn16:5.16.5: And when he falls silent, they’ve never had enough.

translation_text.dn16:5.16.15: These are the four incredible and amazing things about Ānanda.
translation_text.dn16:5.16.16: There are these four incredible and amazing things about a wheel-turning monarch.
translation_text.dn16:5.16.18: If an assembly of aristocrats goes to see a wheel-turning monarch, they’re uplifted by seeing him
translation_text.dn16:5.16.19: and uplifted by hearing him speak.

translation_text.dn16:5.16.25: And when he falls silent, they’ve never had enough.
translation_text.dn16:5.16.26: In the same way, there are those four incredible and amazing things about Ānanda.”
translation_text.dn16:5.17.1: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha:
translation_text.dn16:5.17.2: “Sir, please don’t be fully extinguished in this little hamlet, this jungle hamlet, this branch hamlet.
translation_text.dn16:5.17.3: There are other great cities such as
translation_text.dn16:5.17.4: Campā, Rājagaha, Sāvatthī, Sāketa, Kosambī, and Varanasi.
translation_text.dn16:5.17.5: Let the Buddha be fully extinguished there.
translation_text.dn16:5.17.6: There are many well-to-do aristocrats, brahmins, and householders there who are devoted to the Buddha.
translation_text.dn16:5.17.7: They will perform the rites of venerating the Realized One’s corpse.”
translation_text.dn16:5.17.8: “Don’t say that Ānanda! Don’t say that
translation_text.dn16:5.17.9: this is a little hamlet, a jungle hamlet, a branch hamlet.
translation_text.dn16:5.18.1: Once upon a time there was a king named Mahāsudassana who was a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king. His dominion extended to all four sides, he achieved stability in the country, and he possessed the seven treasures.
translation_text.dn16:5.18.2: His capital was this Kusinārā, which at the time was named Kusāvatī.
translation_text.dn16:5.18.3: It stretched for twelve leagues from east to west, and seven leagues from north to south.
translation_text.dn16:5.18.4: The royal capital of Kusāvatī was successful, prosperous, populous, full of people, with plenty of food.
translation_text.dn16:5.18.5: It was just like Āḷakamandā, the royal capital of the gods, which is successful, prosperous, populous, full of spirits, with plenty of food.
translation_text.dn16:5.18.7: Kusāvatī was never free of ten sounds by day or night, namely:
translation_text.dn16:5.18.8: the sound of elephants, horses, chariots, drums, clay drums, arched harps, singing, horns, gongs, and handbells; and the cry: ‘Eat, drink, be merry!’ as the tenth.
translation_text.dn16:5.19.1: Go, Ānanda, into Kusinārā and inform the Mallas:
translation_text.dn16:5.19.2: ‘This very day, Vāseṭṭhas, in the last watch of the night, the Realized One will be fully extinguished.
translation_text.dn16:5.19.3: Come forth, Vāseṭṭhas! Come forth, Vāseṭṭhas!
translation_text.dn16:5.19.5: ‘The Realized One became fully extinguished in our own village district, but we didn’t get a chance to see him in his final hour.’”
translation_text.dn16:5.19.6: “Yes, sir,” replied Ānanda. Then he robed up and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Kusinārā with a companion.
translation_text.dn16:5.20.1: Now at that time the Mallas of Kusinārā were sitting together at the town hall on some business.
translation_text.dn16:5.20.2: Ānanda went up to them, and announced:
translation_text.dn16:5.20.3: “This very day, Vāseṭṭhas, in the last watch of the night, the Realized One will be fully extinguished.
translation_text.dn16:5.20.4: Come forth, Vāseṭṭhas! Come forth, Vāseṭṭhas!
translation_text.dn16:5.20.6: ‘The Realized One became fully extinguished in our own village district, but we didn’t get a chance to see him in his final hour.’”
translation_text.dn16:5.21.1: When they heard what Ānanda had to say, the Mallas, their sons, daughters-in-law, and wives became distraught, saddened, and grief-stricken. And some, with hair disheveled and arms raised, falling down like their feet were chopped off, rolling back and forth, lamented,
translation_text.dn16:5.21.2: “Too soon the Blessed One will be fully extinguished! Too soon the Holy One will be fully extinguished! Too soon the Eye of the World will vanish!”
translation_text.dn16:5.21.3: Then the Mallas, their sons, daughters-in-law, and wives, distraught, saddened, and grief-stricken went to the Mallian sal grove at Upavattana and approached Ānanda.
translation_text.dn16:5.22.2: “If I have the Mallas pay homage to the Buddha one by one, they won’t be finished before first light.
translation_text.dn16:5.22.3: I’d better separate them family by family and then have them pay homage, saying:
translation_text.dn16:5.22.4: ‘Sir, the Malla named so-and-so with children, wives, retinue, and ministers bows with his head at your feet.’”
translation_text.dn16:5.22.5: And so that’s what he did.
translation_text.dn16:5.22.7: So by this means Ānanda got the Mallas to finish paying homage to the Buddha in the first watch of the night.

translation_text.dn16:5.26.1: Then the wanderer Subhadda went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him. When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:
translation_text.dn16:5.26.2: “Worthy Gotama, there are those ascetics and brahmins who lead an order and a community, and tutor a community. They’re well-known and famous religious founders, deemed holy by many people.
translation_text.dn16:5.26.3: Namely: Pūraṇa Kassapa, the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla, Ajita of the hair blanket, Pakudha Kaccāyana, Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta, and the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan.
translation_text.dn16:5.26.4: According to their own claims, did all of them have direct knowledge, or none of them, or only some?”
translation_text.dn16:5.26.7: I shall teach you the Dhamma.
translation_text.dn16:5.26.8: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.dn16:5.27.1: “Subhadda, in whatever teaching and training the noble eightfold path is not found, there is no ascetic found, no second ascetic, no third ascetic, and no fourth ascetic.
translation_text.dn16:5.27.2: In whatever teaching and training the noble eightfold path is found, there is an ascetic found, a second ascetic, a third ascetic, and a fourth ascetic.

translation_text.dn16:5.30.5: Not long after his ordination, Venerable Subhadda, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. translation_text.dn16:6.13.1: Then the Mallas ordered their men,
translation_text.dn16:6.13.2: “So then, my men, collect fragrances and garlands, and all the musical instruments in Kusinārā.”

translation_text.dn16:6.13.5: “It’s too late to cremate the Buddha’s corpse today. Let’s do it tomorrow.”

translation_text.dn16:6.17.1: Then the Mallas said to Ānanda,
translation_text.dn16:6.17.2: “Honorable Ānanda, how do we proceed when it comes to the Realized One’s corpse?”
translation_text.dn16:6.17.3: “Proceed in the same way as they do for the corpse of a wheel-turning monarch.”
translation_text.dn16:6.17.4: “But how do they proceed with a wheel-turning monarch’s corpse?”
translation_text.dn16:6.17.5: “They wrap a wheel-turning monarch’s corpse with unworn cloth, then with uncarded cotton, then again with unworn cloth.
translation_text.dn16:6.17.6: In this way they wrap the corpse with five hundred double-layers. Then they place it in an iron casket filled with oil and close it up with another casket. Then, having built a funeral pyre out of all kinds of aromatics, they cremate the corpse.
translation_text.dn16:6.17.7: They build a monument for the wheel-turning monarch at the crossroads.
translation_text.dn16:6.17.8: That’s how they proceed with a wheel-turning monarch’s corpse.
translation_text.dn16:6.17.9: Proceed in the same way with the Realized One’s corpse.
translation_text.dn16:6.17.10: A monument for the Realized One is to be built at the crossroads.
translation_text.dn16:6.17.11: When someone there lifts up garlands or fragrance or powder, or bows, or inspires confidence in their heart, that will be for their lasting welfare and happiness.”

translation_text.dn16:6.23.3: It’s like when ghee or oil blaze and burn, and neither ashes nor soot are found.
translation_text.dn16:6.23.4: In the same way, when the Buddha’s corpse was cremated no ash or soot was found from outer or inner skin, flesh, sinews, or synovial fluid.
translation_text.dn16:6.23.6: And of those five hundred pairs of garments only two were not burnt: the innermost and the outermost.
translation_text.dn16:6.23.7: But when the Buddha’s corpse was consumed the funeral pyre was extinguished by a stream of water that appeared in the sky,
translation_text.dn16:6.23.8: by water dripping from the sal trees,
translation_text.dn16:6.23.9: and by the Mallas’ fragrant water.
translation_text.dn16:6.23.10: Then the Mallas made a cage of spears for the Buddha’s relics in the town hall and surrounded it with a buttress of bows. For seven days they honored, respected, revered, and venerated them with dance and song and music and garlands and fragrances.
translation_text.dn16:6.24.1: King Ajātasattu of Magadha, son of the princess of Videha, heard
translation_text.dn16:6.24.2: that the Buddha had become fully quenched at Kusinārā.
translation_text.dn16:6.24.3: He sent an envoy to the Mallas of Kusinārā:
translation_text.dn16:6.24.4: “The Buddha was an aristocrat and so am I. I too deserve a share of the Buddha’s relics. I will build a monument for them and conduct a memorial service.”
translation_text.dn16:6.24.5: The Licchavis of Vesālī also heard
translation_text.dn16:6.24.6: that the Buddha had become fully quenched at Kusinārā.
translation_text.dn16:6.24.7: They sent an envoy to the Mallas of Kusinārā:
translation_text.dn16:6.24.8: “The Buddha was an aristocrat and so are we. We too deserve a share of the Buddha’s relics. We will build a monument for them and conduct a memorial service.”
translation_text.dn16:6.24.9: The Sakyans of Kapilavatthu also heard
translation_text.dn16:6.24.10: that the Buddha had become fully quenched at Kusinārā.
translation_text.dn16:6.24.11: They sent an envoy to the Mallas of Kusinārā:
translation_text.dn16:6.24.12: “The Buddha was our foremost relative. We too deserve a share of the Buddha’s relics. We will build a monument for them and conduct a memorial service.”
translation_text.dn16:6.24.13: The Bulis of Allakappa also heard
translation_text.dn16:6.24.14: that the Buddha had become fully quenched at Kusinārā.
translation_text.dn16:6.24.15: They sent an envoy to the Mallas of Kusinārā:
translation_text.dn16:6.24.16: “The Buddha was an aristocrat and so are we. We too deserve a share of the Buddha’s relics. We will build a monument for them and conduct a memorial service.”
translation_text.dn16:6.24.17: The Koliyans of Rāmagāma also heard
translation_text.dn16:6.24.18: that the Buddha had become fully quenched at Kusinārā.
translation_text.dn16:6.24.19: They sent an envoy to the Mallas of Kusinārā:
translation_text.dn16:6.24.20: “The Buddha was an aristocrat and so are we. We too deserve a share of the Buddha’s relics. We will build a monument for them and conduct a memorial service.”
translation_text.dn16:6.24.21: The brahmin of Veṭhadīpa also heard
translation_text.dn16:6.24.22: that the Buddha had become fully quenched at Kusinārā.
translation_text.dn16:6.24.23: He sent an envoy to the Mallas of Kusinārā:
translation_text.dn16:6.24.24: “The Buddha was an aristocrat and I am a brahmin. I too deserve a share of the Buddha’s relics. I will build a monument for them and conduct a memorial service.”
translation_text.dn16:6.24.25: The Mallas of Pāvā also heard
translation_text.dn16:6.24.26: that the Buddha had become fully quenched at Kusinārā.
translation_text.dn16:6.24.27: They sent an envoy to the Mallas of Kusinārā:
translation_text.dn16:6.24.28: “The Buddha was an aristocrat and so are we. We too deserve a share of the Buddha’s relics. We will build a monument for them and conduct a memorial service.”
translation_text.dn16:6.25.1: When they had spoken, the Mallas of Kusinārā said to those various groups:
translation_text.dn16:6.25.2: “The Buddha was fully quenched in our village district. We will not give away a share of his relics.”
translation_text.dn16:6.25.3: Then Doṇa the brahmin said to those various groups:
translation_text.dn16:6.25.4: “Hear, sirs, a single word from me.
translation_text.dn16:6.25.6: It would not be good to fight over
translation_text.dn16:6.25.7: a share of the supreme individual’s relics.
translation_text.dn16:6.25.8: Let us make eight portions, good fellows,
translation_text.dn16:6.25.10: Let there be monuments far and wide,
translation_text.dn16:6.25.11: so many folk may gain faith in the Clear-eyed One!”
translation_text.dn16:6.25.12: “Well then, brahmin, you yourself should fairly divide the Buddha’s relics in eight portions.”
translation_text.dn16:6.25.13: “Yes, worthy sirs,” replied Doṇa to those various groups. He divided the relics as asked and said to them,
translation_text.dn16:6.25.14: “Sirs, please give me the urn, and I shall build a monument for it and conduct a memorial service.”
translation_text.dn16:6.25.15: So they gave Doṇa the urn.

translation_text.dn16:6.26.3: They sent an envoy to the Mallas of Kusinārā:
translation_text.dn16:6.26.4: “The Buddha was an aristocrat, and so are we. We too deserve a share of the Buddha’s relics. We will build a monument for them and conduct a memorial service.”
translation_text.dn16:6.26.5: “There is no portion of the Buddha’s relics left, they have already been portioned out.
translation_text.dn16:6.27.10: and the Moriyas of Pippalivana built monuments for them and conducted memorial services.
translation_text.dn16:6.27.11: Thus there were eight monuments for the relics, a ninth for the urn, and a tenth for the embers.
translation_text.dn16:6.27.12: That is how it was in the old days.
translation_text.dn16:6.28.1: There were eight shares <j>of the Clear-eyed One’s relics.
translation_text.dn16:6.28.2: Seven were worshipped in the Black Plum Tree Land.
translation_text.dn16:6.28.3: But one share of the most excellent of men
translation_text.dn16:6.28.4: was worshipped in Rāmagāma by a dragon king.
translation_text.dn16:6.28.5: One tooth is venerated by the gods of the Third Heaven,
translation_text.dn16:6.28.6: and one is worshipped in the city of Gandhāra;
translation_text.dn16:6.28.7: another one in the realm of the Kaliṅga King,
translation_text.dn16:6.28.8: and one is worshipped by a dragon king.
translation_text.dn16:6.28.9: Through their glory this rich earth
translation_text.dn16:6.28.10: is adorned with the best of offerings.
translation_text.dn16:6.28.12: is well honored by the honorable.
translation_text.dn16:6.28.13: It’s venerated by lords of gods, dragons, and spirits;
translation_text.dn16:6.28.14: and likewise venerated by the finest lords of men.
translation_text.dn16:6.28.15: Honor it with joined palms when you get the chance,
translation_text.dn16:6.28.16: for a Buddha is rare even in a hundred eons.
translation_text.dn16:6.28.18: and the body hair and head hair,
translation_text.dn16:6.28.19: were carried off individually by gods
